div.head: I WATCHâD THE HEAVENS.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: I WATCHâD the heavâns above me, and a star
Appearâd before my meditative eyes;
I markâd the solitary beam afar
Pursue its journey in thâ eternal skies.
Calm from its distant glory, came the rays
Through all of space between us, on my gaze;
No other signs of those who dwelt therein
Fell on my sense, except that beam serene;
And fancy, soothed beneath the streaming light,
Pursued the orb along its high career,
And deemâd it some new world, all fresh and bright
With its ten thousand hopes, and not one fear.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: There did I land, upborne on wondrous wing,
On whose strong pinion the freed spirit flies;
And markâd around in many a beauteous thing,
How, like our earth, it might be paradise.
Serene and sweet the lovely landscape lay
Outstretchâd beneath a summerâs glancing ray;
And from blue skies a fostâring sun like ours,
Swellâd in the fruits, and glitterâd in the flowârs.
Above, the silent mountains stood on high,
Their outline graved distinct along the sky;
And forests stretchâd their undulating wreath,
Above the vales that smiling slept beneath;
While far away, the breath of fresh perfume
Passâd on the breeze which rose from western caves,
And oâer the glow of summerâs form and bloom,
Calm oceanâs voice came up from slowly moving waves.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Manâs mind, if turned harmonious to the scene,
Might here have felt its glory all expand;
Reason, and joy, and feeling, would have been
Callâd forth and echoâd in that lovely land.
Here dwelt that spell upon the mountainâs brow,
Which calls to life the bosomâs generous glow;
Here smiled that spirit on the mirror lake,
From which our feelings holy calmness take;
And breeze, and bloom, and change of night and day,
Held commune with the soulâs more noble part;
And fain would lead it, on its destined way,
All dignified the mind, all calm and good the heart.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: âO Thou, whose ample page, if read aright,
Stirs the immortal in the mortalâs breast,
If here there dwell a race not fallen quite,
They are already, or they may be blessâd;
For thou hast lovâd this newâfound Globe to dress,
And make it fit for Eden happiness;
And if its dwellers like itself be pure,
Glory and Peace will mantle oâer their doom;
Man here might see his promised hope secureâ
This is, perchance, the shore whose ocean is the tomb.â

lg.head: V.
lg.l: While thus I ponderâd, onward came a form,
Unlike the dream which flatterâd Fancyâs sight,
Manâs shape he wore, but some internal storm
Defaced the image, and put out its light.
His inward spirit seemâd by thoughts oâercast
Whose shadow oâer his visage darkly passâd,
And to his eye that lovely land was dim,
Suggesting nought of peace or joy to himâ
He heard no accent in the wind, and flood,
The landscape had no meanings for his eye,
In vain before him in their joy they stood,
For joyâs responding sources in his heart were dry.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: âBeing!âwhat art thou?â I exclaimâd, and gazed
In wonder on his stricken form and face;
On me his haggard eyes he slowly raised,
And paused a few short moments in his place.
I know not what of deadly pain there came
In gradual current through his shaken frame,
But while he markâd me, old Remembrance seemâd
To pass before him with its phantom crew,
Like one who fainting on the rock has dreamâd
Of childhoodâd scenes, which crowd his thoughts anew,
Forgot through guilty yearsâbut oh, how dear and true!

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: âAnd what art thou?â he answerâd me. âCanst thou,
A mortal, stand still mortal on this shore?
Back, back to earth, manâs happiest dream to knowâ
Dream thou shalt dieâDeath comes to us no more!â
With that he tossâd his weary arms on high,
And lookâd despairing at the sunny sky,
While cold dews rose upon his ashy brow,
Wrung fiercely from his inward agony,
As though he felt the curse upon him now,
The everlasting doom, the fixâd command, to be.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: âDeath comes not here?â I cried; âO spirit, say,
Why dwells then on thy face that print of pain;
This land seems one where joyful souls might stray,
And find their home, their native heavân again.â
Darkly he answerâdââAy, if place could make
That joy wherein the soul aspires to dwell;
The land, the land, perchance, such thoughts may wakeâ
Ay, all around is heaven, but here within is hell.â

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: So saying, on the ground his form he threw,
And gnashâd the herbs around him in his woe,
Then his clenchâd hand towards the skies he threw,
And gibberâd words like hate, but short and low,
Forced through closed teeth, as though his inward pain
Sought something to accuse, and sought in vain.
At length his eyes upon my face he turnâd,
Where fire, like tombâlamps lit by sorrow, burnâd,
And bade me forwardââGo, and see beyond,
The fallen spirits, and the scene they suitâ
God to their guidance leaves the outcast land,
Sin works its will uncheckâdâgo see its gracious fruit!â

lg.head: X.
lg.l: I wanderâd onward, stricken with his word,
And lookâd for some new form as dread as this;
But yet no sound of voice or step was heard,
And nature smiled in her untroubled bliss.
Deep quiet vistas of green wood uprose,
And flowârs beneath illumined their repose;
When sunbeams piercing through the quivâring shade,
Shot changeful brightness up the summer glade.
At length, where hung above the flood, a tree,
I saw a shape, sit tranquil as the scene;
And deemâd the sentence not for him, and he
Was there rejoicing, and rejoiced by Natureâs mien.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: But as I gazed, a horror oâer me came,
Like one who enters in a gloomy place,
And there, with doubtful eyes and startled frame,
Sees from the darkness grow a form and face.
Changed was that face, and dim the look it wore,
Yet still it was the same I knew of yore;
But, oh! how alterâd from that happier day,
When mind shone through it with its fiery ray!
Keen, joyous, thenâand in those hours of earth,
Whateâer he touchâd became a brighter thing;
Eâen vice, when he would wreathe it, in his mirth,
Grew fair beneath the flowers which oâer it he would fling.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: Stilly he sat, but on his hueless cheek
âTwas no elysian peace that fixâd its reign,
But brooding stillness, whose dark shadows speak
Of reason lost in a benighted brain.
And that quick eye, which, glittering once with wit,
Markâd and adornâd each form that courted it,
Now heavily was fixâd on one lone spot,
And even there beheld, but markâd it not.
His lips had sunk asunder; and the smile
That came like lightning seemed extinct for ever;
His slackenâd brow was blank of light the while,
Where glowâd his genius once, as though to perish never.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: I callâd him by his nameâhe did not mark;
His fame, it seemâd forgotten in his doom;
Like the silk pennon on a sinking bark,
Or witherâd flowârs upon a lastâyearâs tomb.
Then from my memory, words of his I brought,
Wherein he once had clothâd a splendid thought,
And he lookâd up as though the pausing dart
Which pressâd before, now enterâd in his heart.
âGoneâgone!â he cried, and one expiring ray
Of mind returnâd, to shew how thick the night,
Then vanishâd in the gathâring clouds away,
Like storms dispersed a moment ere they quench the light.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: âArt thou so fallen?â I exclaimâdââWhat, thou?
Earthâworshippâd man, our glory, and our grace,â
Where is the wreath which twines thy statueâs brow?
Where is thâ Elysium which we deemâd thy place?â
âThou speakest language of a world gone by,â
Slowly he answeredââlowest, last am I.â
And while he spoke, I thought of time behind,
When once beside a dotardâs seat he stood,
Mocking the dull face, in his pride of mindâ
Then, how unlike his own! how near his present mood!

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: âYet, once,â I answerâd, âwords were not so fleet,
But thou hadst caught their sense before âtwas said;
Things dark to others thou wouldst halfâway meet,
And turn them all to daylight âmid the shade.â
âAm I as then?â he answerâd. âThen I was
Happy.â He spoke, and dismal was the pause;
Then round he gazed on the delicious landâ
But to his eyes, alas! âtwas dull and voidâ
And murmurâd, stretching forth each empty hand,
âI feel existence only, which I once enjoyâd.â

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: âThis is thy penance, then,â I cried; but he,
In such dull accents as before, repliedâ
âAy, call it penance, if such name may be
To things by nature joinâd in one, applied.
Ay, penance, for I might have been as high
As Joy can lead a dweller of the sky,
If passions brought from earth had not decayâd
This subtle frame, for Joy and Virtue made;
But they have bowâd and rent it, till behold
The hopeless, helpless wretch that I am grown;
Earth was the place to check them or unfoldâ
Cruel as true thy word, my penance is my own.â

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: Pitying I heard; but while mine ear I bent,
Arose a cry that spoke the extreme of ill,
Prolongâd by passion when the breath was spent,
Renewâd again ere one might say âtis still.
And, oh, what mingled dread was surging thence!
Fear, furyâs yell, and agony intense;
And of some deed, some sight,âthe story told,
I dared not think on, yet must fain behold;
And, rushing headlong toward the sounding place,
Through bush and brake I strove to force my way,
As one who would behold a murderâd face
Tears off the pall in haste, too fearful to delay.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: And thereâoh Heaven! oh Heaven!âthat fearful sight!
Man, what a fiend, when turned to ill, art Thou!
What aspects human eyes and thoughts to blight,
Tortured and torturer, met my glances now!
For both uprose before meâboth, too, wore
Manâs form, and yet a human form no more;
But shaped by inner thoughts, till they were grown
Things that the mortal eye neâer lookâd upon.
One fastenâd to a stake was writing there,
With hellâs own aspect on his form and face,
And round, the inflictors stood, on whom Despair
Was written with another, but an equal trace.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: Where are the burning words that paint the pains
By spirits on their fellowâspirits wrought?
Things which earthâs tyrant racks and dungeon chains
But shadow forth, as speech interprets thought.
Not human pain was there, for that can slay,
And from the man divide the suffering clay;
But pangs that pressâd on naked mind their smart,
And lived with life in each immortal part;
Such as inflame on earth, the torturerâs willâ
The eager will which leaves his powâr behind;
The will, the power, in hell are present still,
But that wherewith, whereon, they work is Mind.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: In vain I strive to pain the howâthe why;
Earth has no words to fix thâ unearthly thingâ
The outer signs they wrung from Misery,
The tone, the look, the act, are all I sing;
And, oh! how howlâd upon the ethers sleep
The load of shrieks from that unceasing lip;
How flashâd the light that elsewhere slept serene,
In horrid lightning from that frantic mien!
Passionâs extremest utterance, mingled wild
With pain, a load of wrong and rage to wreak;
At times, the inflicting host his voice reviled
In words which might have ruinâd worlds to speakâ
At times himself he wailâd in that blaspheming shriek.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: Around, not less demoniac, shewâd the crew,
Tossing and wild, like some tempestuous wave;
Each with fresh torture heapâd his pain anew,
And bitter speech increased the pang they gave.
Unknown to them satiety of painâ
Unknown Remorse, which, waking not in vain
On earth, amid her worst and fiercest band,
Holds from the last excess the shrinking hand;
But these no sympathizing feelings knew,
By which man makes the cause of man his own;
No saving influence the hand withdrew,
Where all alike had powâr, and pity dwelt with none.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: All who from him had sufferâd wrong were there,
Whose souls, debased, for vengeance thirsted still;
All he compellâd on earth his yoke to bear,
By fortune slaves, but tyrants by their will.
Nor were earthâs debts alone to be defrayâdâ
He lived in hell the tyrant he had died;
And spirits here the recent wrong repaid
With eager haste upon his conquerâd head.
âRemember earthâremember hell!â they said;
âThis, for the long passâd, long rememberâd wrong;
And this, for yesterdayâs still burning deed,
For which we thank our fate thou hast not waited long.â

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: With wild demoniac laugh they urged their glee,
For frighted lookâd they with their own success,
Like one who, murdâring his worst enemy,
Grows mad with his loud cry and struggling face.
And he, their victim, shriekâd, till all among
The vales and hills one voice of torment rung;
And ghastly shapes came forth in living swarms,
Peopling the sunny rocks with dismal forms,
And markâd the maddâning scene, till some flung high
Their tossing arms, and joinâd the frantic cry,
And some approachâd with staring eyes, as though
To harden hearts, not yet quite hard to woe;
And some affrighted, fled with speed, that fain
Would find a refuge âgainst the direful crew;
And crazed with fear, came full in sight again,
Then strainâd their weary limbs, and, shrieking, fled anew.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: I heardâI saw the deepening horror roll,
Increasing ever as the moments fled;
Till like some lengthenâd storm it mazed the soul,
And, like a mist, was fear around them spread.
I saw not individual crime or woe,
A troubled sea, it raged and burst below,
Till, like the taper shining on the shore,
Which shews the stormâtossâd bark its port once more,
A form across the raving people pressâd,
Whose heart one human feeling still possessâd:
I saw him stoop and loose the wretchesâ chain,
And they, it may be, tired, allowâd the deedâ
âWe meet as erst on earth,â he said; âAgain,
Old comrade, will I aid thy hour of need.â

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: Released, he fled at onceâyet turnâd to shout
A yell of rage that sank to agony;
And from their gatherâd ranks a cry rang out
Of mockery, bitter as the fiendsâ could be.
But faster fled heâFear was stronger then
Than even Vengeance, hot in every vein;
And with a watchful eye, I turnâd to mark
How, refuge âgainst his fellowâkind to gain,
He sought the waving forest cool and dark,
While oâer him bent the tree alleviating his pain.

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: Intent to bring relief, more near I drew;
But, starting, fearful, when my words began,
He draggâd his limbs oâer earth in flight anew,
Like some crushâd serpent at the sight of man.
In vain I sought to reâassure his dreadâ
In vain to quench it by some kindly deedâ
Wingâd by his fear, his quivâring frame he sped,
And Fear became more fearful as he fled;
Till âneath the roots of an oâerhanging tree,
Which from the bank a little space was set,
Groaning, he crawlâd, and turnâd to gaze on me,
Coilâd in his narrow nook, and glaring Fear and Hate.

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: I left him, hopelessly, and wandered on,
All doleful sounds, all dreary sights among,
And eâen where Heavenâs light best and brightest shone,
Methought the night of mind most darkly hung.
Some sat in the sunâs rays, and markâd it rise
Along its daily pathway of the skies,
With vacant eye, which knew to them âtwould be
The same one hour through all eternity.
Some built such fabrics as on earth express
Manâs pomp or pride, and when aloft they grew,
Smote them to dust again for weariness,
And then for weariness began their work anew.

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: There toilâd in the vain labour many an one,
Whose wishes lingerâd in the world behind,
Coilâd round the things and creatures that were goneâ
The haunting phantoms of his cumberâd mind.
There stood the man, whose transitory pleasure
Had been Earthâs glittering joys, or golden treasure;
And who revived, amid a world destroyâd,
To live when all was dead that he enjoyâd.
Amazed with objects which had met his eye
When reâawaking, he arose from death;
He turnâd to look for earth, and saw it lie
Expiring in its flames, with all he loved beneath.

lg.head: XXIX.
lg.l: Not far apart, the Conqueror, who had fought
To make himself a name, stood nameless by;
One spot of earth had been the prize he sought,
Whose whole orb now had faded from the sky;
And round throâ that Existence infiniteâ
He, restless, turnâd his everâwandâring sight,
Gazing through worlds which shone with countless flame,
For that within whose bound he left his fame;
But none that Fame rememberâd, and he grew
A vacant wandârer, past remembrance riven;
Save when some giber of the demon crew
Mockâd at the homage he on earth had given.

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: Beyond these, some had tried to bring anew
Timeâs pleasures into vast eternity;
The sound of music round the circle flew,
And forms went flitting to its melody.
But seemâd it, as if one who watchâd the bed
Where all he loved the best, in death was laid,
Should rise, and in the dead oneâs presence play
The idle games that pleased him yesterday.
For strange the eyes I markâd among the group,
And haggard pale the cheeks, and slack the mien,
While to these sports unconscious did they stoop,
Pondâring far other thoughts meantime within.

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: And one by one they stoppâd, as though the heart
Failâd at the endless echo of the strain;
Gazed in each otherâs face and turnâd apart,
Or sat them down, as neâer to rise again.
And smile or laugh was not; for they who yet
Moved to the music did it as a debt,
And seemâd to feel it was a pain to be,
The pain of vacant immortality;
Till all, at last, were still; and then the sound
Of the gay, grievous strain, was heard the more,
Recurring still with its perpetual round,
Dead language of Delight, whose life was oâer.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: Methought that there were none more lost to God
Than souls on former pleasures so employâd,
Who, with all Heaven appointed their abode,
Clung to the shadows of a world destroyâd.
And when I saw Mindâs vast capacity
Wheel lagging round a little point, and be
A burden to itself from day to day,
I bowâd lamenting, oâer their former pride,
As when the Magian swept a world away,
Over its ruinâd beauty, spirits sighâd.*

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: Soulâstruck, I turnâd away; and from the throng
Went musing on, while still the weary strain
Came with its joyless melody along,
Repeating in my ear its antic pain.
And some I saw, who cast them down, and laid,
Hearing the sound, in their clenchâd hand, their head,
As though they could not brook that earthly voice,
Which once they answered when it said, Rejoice.
And some, in quicker ecstasy of woe,
Cried out aloud, and tossâd them at the tone,
As though lifeâs pain again were running through
A form by Torture almost turnâd to stone.

lg.head: XXXIV.
lg.l: But now I left behind those sounds of wail,
And followâd where grey rocks on either side
Rose up aloft above a narrow vale,
And in the sunâs light bathed their brows of pride.
But all below was shadowâd, and so still,
I heard the long grass move upon the hill.
Here hell was silent, and it seemâd almost
The inward fire might lave itself to rest,
If one could stand alone, of that wild host,
Mid the grave calmness of the mountainâs breast.
And to them, truly, it had seemâd a place
Where Quiet still might find one sacred spot;
For, as I turnâd a vast rockâs jutting baseâ
A scene before me lay which I have not forgot.

lg.head: XXXV.
lg.l: Tall Cypress trees had rearâd themselves on high,
About a mountainâs foot that closâd the view;
And resting in its bed, a lake lay by,
Repeating point and line, precise and true.
No breeze disturbâd it in its deep serene;
No moving thing reflected life therein;
A changeless copy of the scene it lent,
Which rose above it motionless; its face
In the mysterious mirror downward bent,
Fixâd, yet unreal, like the forms in Memoryâs glass.

lg.head: XXXVI.
lg.l: And there, between the water and the trees,
The spirits had erected tombs, like those
Which Earth in every tranquil churchyard sees,
Yielding to sad and gay the same repose.
To me, too, seemâd they quiet; for my mind
Had with such outer, inner calm combinâd;
And I believed that in this place of rest,
The sentence of the spirit was unbound;
And gazed upon each hillockâs awful breast,
Where mind, annihilationâs peace had found.

lg.head: XXXVII.
lg.l: But while I gazed, from the vaultâs hollow cave
Crawlâd shapes, still animate with living breath,
As comes the unquiet worm from out the grave,
Where, living, dwells he in the house of death;
Clothed in the garments of the dead were they,
The shroud and cerement of corrupting clay;
And from our own earthâs vault and sepulchre,
Whatever told of death they copied there.
With vain desire they longâd aside to fling
Their newâborn weight of immortality,
And yearning tâward earthâs last and lowest thing,
Made all their aim and purpose, not to be.

lg.head: XXXVIII.
lg.l: But there they sat on the graveâs edge, and sighâd,
And saw the scene around with sleepless eye,
That roved unquiet oâer the breathless tide,
Or wanderâd upward through the sunny sky;
Then turnâd again toward the narrow tomb,
Till grew another hope from out the gloom;
And rising, with the deathâclothes round them, pressâd
The heavy foldings, corpseâlike, on their breast;
And once again descending, laid them there,
Extended still, and straight upon the bier.
But rest they could not; and the quivâring lid
Struggled and openâd from the eye once more;
And, forcâd again to leave deathâs mimic bed,
They rose, and left the grave all deathless as before.

lg.head: XXXIX.
lg.l: One, more than all, hung clingingly on death,
And longest lay in copy of his form;
Nor seemâd to quit the shadowy place beneath,
Till driven to motion by his bosomâs storm.
Then, as an exile meets a strangerâs land,
He turnâd to life, from whose detested strand
He gazed upon the tomb with such despair,
Such yearning wishes in his look confessâd,
As though he said, âMy spiritâs home is thereâ
My country! wherefore dost thou spurn me from thy breast?â

lg.head: XL.
lg.l: Then, on a stone he sat him down, beside
The water, where it joinâd the margin sand;
And on the shore, left arid by the tide,
He shaped out letters with a slender wand.
I drew toward him, asking why he mournâd?
And he his witherâd face upon me turnâd,
And answerâd, (pointing to the sand below,
With sorrowâs languid hand,) âThere lies my woe.â
I lookâd, and saw the many lines he made,
Varied in every form, yet still the same;
For there his thoughts their lone impression laid,
And in a thousand characters had traced one name.

lg.head: XLI.
lg.l: âThariaâ and âTharia,â written on the ground,
Met him whereâer below he turnâd his sight;
To him, perchance, the name was magicâbound,
And told a form all love, an eye all light.
But nought I saw, except the writerâs hand
That stampâd a female name upon the sand;
And askâd him whom and what those letters brought,
With faithful symbol, back on memory?
And where was passâd the being of his thought,
That thus he mournâd her in eternity?

lg.head: XLII.
lg.l: âNo more with me!â he said; âthe grave received
That form from out my arms, whose shade will be
With lifeâs whole texture ever interweaved,
Though life now spreads to immortality.
Here lies her image, like the corpse of one
From whom the friend, the soul, the self is gone;
A lamp, in a deserted house, that burns,
Lit by a hand that never more returns.
That face of placid quiet, is not herâs
Whom every change of mine erewhile could move;
That eye no longer at my presence stirs,
Which was the mirror to my joy, my grief, my love.â

lg.head: XLIII.
lg.l: âHow parted ye?â I askâd; âWhat fate severe
Forbade to both one common destiny?
Alas! if thou aspiredst not with her,
How âscapâd the thing belovâd, to sink with thee?â
âNo, no!â he answerâd; âshe with purer eyes,
Lookâd through earthâs gladness to the gladder skies;
A bird, that resting in a midâway land,
Loves that, but better loves the home beyond!
Gladly she went; although her eyesâ last ray
Lingerâd, and callâd me through the shadows dim;
But from myself I cast that hope away,
Forgetting God in grief, and losing all with him.

lg.head: XLIV.
lg.l: I thought of her alone on earth; of her
Alone, beyond the bounds of earth and time;
All other objects were forgot that stir
The spirit to a strife for scenes sublime.
Earth was a desert, death was her abodeâ
I thought not how the life beyond it glowâd;
Few flitting years were doomâd our hearts to severâ
But I have changed the parting to For Ever.
For fondly to the grave I turnâd, and there
Believed was meeting, and my soulâs relief;
Or hoped, at least, to die to my despair,
And did the murmurerâs act, the suicide of grief.

lg.head: XLV.
lg.l: âBut oh, we met not!ââtis not death that brings
The hearts together whom his hands divide;
Beyond his empire rose immortal things,
Which, madmanâlike, I laid my thoughts aside;
Truth, Glory, Goodness, and the Spiritâs strength,
Wrought out from all earthâs trialâwoes, at length,
Alone, are dwellers of that happier clime,
Where she rejoices in her fate sublime;
I saw her, and the grief which oâer her threw,
Beholding what I was, its mortal hue,
Clearâd cloudâlike from her face, as, new and bright,
Heaven shed on her accepted soul its light.
And then for ever parted, eâen in thought,
She entered with no backward look, her rest,
Unseen her place, my place by her unsought,
We never meet again; and she by that is blessâd.â

lg.head: XLVI.
lg.l: âHad she been like thee, thou wert happy then?
Together ye had dwelt, and that were bliss?â
Thus eagerly I questioned him, to win
His answer to an anxious thought like this.
âAy, perfect bliss!â he cried; yet while he said,
Like one by self denied, he sank his head;
And glancâd toward a neighbouring tomb, where leant
Two figures on the uprearâd monument.
One was their Fate; one World, one ceaseless Life;
United, earthâlike, save with closer doom;
Yet worn they lookâd, as with the spiritâs strife,
And chose, as emblem of their wish, a tomb.

lg.head: XLVII.
lg.l: Silent they sate upon the vaulted den
Which other hands, in other days, had rearâd;
And which the first indwellers quitted, when
The hope for which they built it, disappearâd.
Their hands were joinâd, it seemâd, because, of old,
It was their wont each otherâs hands to fold;
Their eyes no more were tâward each other raised,
Or conscious that fond looks upon them gazed;
But various and apart, as though the thought
Of either heart, no common centre sought.
The womanâs wanderâd oâer the land serene,
Restless and seeking, and yet hopeless now;
The manâs were all unconscious of the scene,
Fixâd on one point, beneath his gatherâd brow.

lg.head: XLVIII.
lg.l: I stood and gazed at distance, and it seemâd
As though their deathlessness on them too weighâd;
And love, which bright enough for earth had beamâd,
Here a faint insufficient twilight made.
The heart, enlarged by immortality,
Seemâd void of half that it had room to hold;
An empty palace, bare to wind and sky,
Prepared for kingâlike pomp, but desert, worn, and cold.

lg.head: XLIX.
lg.l: I passâd them slowly by; perusing still
Their languid attitude and careless mien;
But did not question; for their spiritâs ill
Enough in every look and line was seen.
He markâd me not; but she, with restless sight,
Caught on the wave my shadow oâer the light;
Then smiled so new a face to see, and took
Her hand from his, yet turnâd again to look
If stirrâd no jealous feeling at the deed,
Or if the stranger woke no sleeping pain;
But no, he did but fold the arms she freed;
Then sitting down she sighâd, and sought his hand again.

lg.head: L.
lg.l: I also sighâd; for she was fair and bright,
And might have been the angel she was not;
Yet was her beauty dayâs decaying light,
And faintly told of radiance half forgot.
It was the wreck of feelings warm and high,
That hallowâd once, and honourâd still, her eye;
Feelings which, worthy to expand in heaven,
To things too mean had been too rashly given;
Like lightning, which, if aimâd aright, would be
Life to an altar pile, to God upraised;
But wasted on the cold unkindly sea,
Dies on the element whereon awhile it blazed.

lg.head: LI.
lg.l: Grieved at the fall of one so fair, I moved
With pensive step and heavy heart away;
And forward through the place of tombs I roved,
Whereâer the path invited me to stray.
Tenantless graves and unfillâd shrouds lay round,
Adding new horror to the barren ground;
Those earthy beds had lost their tenants now,
And wore not eâen the image of repose;
Forth in the world they had resolved to go,
To seek, though not to hope, some refuge from their woes.

lg.head: LII.
lg.l: Here where most mournful, was the mournful place
Deserted, barren, hopeless, and accurst,
Sate scatterâd far upon the tombâgrown grass,
Some who, mid all things drear, still sought the worst;
Erewhile on earth they bowâd âneath sorrowâs storm,
Sinking to dust their unelastic form;
And if one joy from out their fate was reft,
Refused to see all comfort that was left.
Eâen in the common pangs of human care
Themselves inflamed the wound that tore their breast;
And fond of anguish, jealous of despair,
They claimâd to be earthâs mourners most oppressâd.

lg.head: LIII.
lg.l: In this new world, from all that soothed they turnâd,
And eâen the straggling sunbeam shut from view;
Save where upon some barren rock it burnâd,
Where flowers grew not, nor rose the nurtâring dew.
They sate by arid sand, and tomb forlorn,
Dry stones by winterâs current searâd and worn,
Where hands despairing, ere they came, had rent
Each green herb climbing oâer the monument.
For those who built them, sought a place which shewâd
Congenial temper to a grieving mind;
But these had chosen the forlorn abode,
To feed the sullen thoughts they fain would make or find.

lg.head: LIV.
lg.l: Oh me! they were so wretched! The long flow
Of age on age had deepenâd their despair;
The shadows which began on earth to grow,
Flung their unbounded shroud about them here.
Thick darkness darkenâd more, as round them flowâd
The ceaseless youth of this unblessâd abode,
Till grief became the food whereon they fed,
Thâ essential substance of their very frame;
Their soulâs one thought, their spiritâs needful dread,
Their element of life, an everâgnawing flame.

lg.head: LV.
lg.l: Chillâd with their aspect, motionless and cold,
At little distance did I sit me down,
Like him a serpentâs fascinations hold,
And fixâd my eyes upon the eyes of one.
Not by my pencil can the gloom be shewn
That oâer his awful lineaments was thrownâ
Drawn lips were there, all colourless and fixâd;
Glassy, yet living eyes; their ray unmixâd
With eâen a motion, that might speak within
The heart less frozen than the icy mien.
His was the shrunken limb, all still and drear,
The rigid hands that held the heavy brow;
As though for years the soul had ceased to stir
The heart to hope, the frame to move, the thoughts to flow.

lg.head: LVI.
lg.l: By slow degrees accustomâd to the sight,
I nearer drew and touchâd with awe his hand;
Then bolder pressâd it, that thâ arousing might
Of outer things might break the spiritâs band.
He stirrâd at length; his stony eyes rose slow,
And fixâd on mine their blank cold gaze of woe:
But wordless for a space, until at last
My boldness raisâd his spirit from its shroud,
The oâer his face a brief fierce radiance passâd,
As leaps the flame once more from some consumed abode.

lg.head: LVII.
lg.l: âWhat dost thou, and what wilt thou, rude unknown?â
Thus spoke a voice half buried in its breast;
It seemâd the echo of a world long gone,
Which should have slept ere now, and been at rest.
âWhat has thy asking face, thy idle bloom,
To do where nature shares the spiritâs gloom?
Hast thou not yet renounced the futile strife
Of those who think their early dreams are true?
Earth might have shewn, since thou art cursed with life,
That thou no more shalt cease the fatal gift to rue.â

lg.head: LVIII.
lg.l: âNot yet,â I cried, âhas it been rued,â for I
Who loved existence started at his word;
âSad should I be to feel lifeâs fountain dry,
Which healthfully my bosomâs pulse has stirrâd.
Some bitter waters I have drunk therein,
And on its surface early iceâflakes seen;
Some forms, which once their dear reflection gave,
No more are imaged on the ruffled wave;
And hues I saw there, âneath the dawning sky,
Have melted as the noonâday hour drew nigh.
Yet as they vanish, other colours rise,
And paint the stream whose course I love to feel,
Fresh from its waves elastic pleasure flies,
And reasonâs calmer joys forth from the current steal.â

lg.head: LIX.
lg.l: Uprose that figure as I paused, and laughâd;
Eâen such a sound might burst from forth the dead,
And on the watcherâs soul dismay engraft,
Who kept his vigil by the sheeted bed.
Still as the corpse was every muscle fixâd,
The cheeks blank whiteness, as before, unmixâd;
That hollow laugh no human feeling spoke,
No smile, no sparkle mingled with the sound,
And âmid the desert silence which it broke,
Rang the harsh voice, unnaturally round.

lg.head: LX.
lg.l: Rousâd at the accent, from full many a grave
Upraisâd the spectreâforms their doleful head;
To mark what lip this troubled accent gave,
That broke the ageâkept silence of their bed.
Their sunken eyes gleamâd out upon the day,
Like tapers dying in the solar ray;
Their forms like wounded earthâworms heavy weighâd
In thâ unaccustomâd effort that they made;
And some fell back to where they lay before;
Others retainâd the change they had assumed,
And settling darkly in their thoughts of yore,
To every outer thing their senselessness resumed.

lg.head: LXI.
lg.l: A few around us came, dark ghosts and pale,â
No beam of man or angel in their eye;
And joinâd their gaze to him who heard my tale,
And scannâd me mockingly, I knew not why.
I to their gaze returnâd such glance as came
Forth from the kindling soulâs excited flame;
For what had they to do with scorn and me?
Forfeit in them the rights that still were mine;
And they, lost spirits! were no longer free
To seek the further bourne, where human grows divine.

lg.head: LXII.
lg.l: Pity I had for aught so lowly sunk;
But pity brookâd not from these less than men.
Should they deride the heavân whence they had shrunk,
And mock the goal which they had failâd to gain?
Yet Anger melted, eâen as it had done.
Should madmen seek to touch some saner one;
He patiently would hear them tell that light
No longer from the sun pourâd forth its ray;
And having listenâd to their tale of night,
Go forth and take the sun to guide his onward way.

lg.head: LXIII.
lg.l: âYoung stranger,â said the phantom, âThou art he
Who, some have told in my regardless ear,
Art wafted from the realms of earth to be
A transient dweller in this distant sphere.
Still haunt thine eye those beams, illumed in vain,
Which, once extinguishâd, never light again;
The beams of hope, which only childhood wears,
Quenchâd ere our manhood by a thousand tears.
But thou art still upon the verge of life;
Deceived full oft, but not enough deceived;
And dreamâst of days with better fortunes rife,â
Ay, I too, once, in Hope, the shadowâs shade, believed.

lg.head: LXIV.
lg.l: âYon world upon me openâd bright and fairâ
Or seeming fair; and with a painted brow
Smiled on my trusting eye, as free from care,
And drew the mask before its inward woe.
Urged by the inborn impulse of my soul,
I sprang to joy, and drainâd the offerâd bowl;
And yet that world, eâen while I drank delight,
Droppâd poison in, the wine of life to blight.
It mimickâd Love, Joy, Friendshipâs, Beautyâs glow,
Yet scarce the wine was sweet, all gall the lees;
The pleasure maddenâd, and the after woe
Struck in my trusting heat its serpent agonies.

lg.head: LXV.
lg.l: âI shared with one my thoughts, my heart, my home
He was my half of lifeâmy all of joy:
That friend deceived,âere long I was become
His fortuneâs toolâhis pleasureâs barterâd toy.
I loved a form that shone upon my way,
As âtwere the guardian planet of my day.
I followâd blindly on the luring beam,
Nor heeded where it led, nor whom it crossâd
Then when âtwas loveliest, the mocking dream
Dissolved in air; and with it all was lost.

lg.head: LXVI.
lg.l: âFarewell, then, to the world; I did not leave
My curse on that scornâd too much to hate;
But from my heart I loosed the ties that weave
A chain betwixt it and our human fate.
Bright creatures passâd me, but I would not love,
Earthâs woeful children, but they did not move;
Men hoped and wept, desired, felt, labourâd, thought;
And I stood by and smiled at all they sought.
What had the heart they wrung to do with them?
It once had answerâd every human cry
But taught by scorn the scorners to contemn,
I turned my heartâs dark side to every mortal eye.

lg.head: LXVII.
lg.l: âSo lived Iâall forgettingâhalf forgot,â
Wrappâd in myself, a world that was mine own;
Nor God nor man had eased my dreary lot,
And I could teach myself to live alone.
So died Iâay, my dog was couchâd beside,
And lickâd my hand; I felt it as I died.
No human thing then feignâd the grief he felt;
No eyes shed tears, I had but ill believed;
I went, and left whom Promise still could melt,
To be lured on like meâlike me, too, undeceived.

lg.head: LXVIII.
lg.l: âI have been lonelyâI am lonely still;
I dug all tenderness from out my heart;
There is no fibre of the smiling ill
To grow out again, to torture, and depart.
I sit and muse, as I have mused before,
And darker grow the wrongs I ponder oâer.
More cursed the doom of the immortal soul,
More evil all the universal whole.
My powers of mind go forth, and learn despair,
My powers of heart are dried. What oozes on
Was wont upon a dog to spend its care;
It fastens now upon this rifted stone.â

lg.head: LXIX.
lg.l: âThy griefs are half thine own, mine all of Fate,â
Another Phantom of the circle cried;
I turnâd, and markâd him, where deject he sate,
Contrasted with the formerâs gloom of pride.
Not altogether so defaced with woe
Was human glory on his pallid brow;
Not so forlorn in selfâmade solitude,
Banishâd from God and man, appearâd his mood.
It rather seemâd the soulâs elastic wing,
Formâd to grow strong on earth, expand in heaven,
Had sufferâd earthly storms to damp its spring,
And could not soar at last,ârelaxâd, decayâd, and riven.

lg.head: LXX.
lg.l: âI askâd not much,â he said; and milder flowâd
His words and tone, as though less searâd his heart;
âMy native land was all I knew of good,
My joy to dwell, my torture to depart.
The scene, the speech, the visage, which had grown
First on my ear and heart stood there alone;
Colours wherein my mind its forms had weaved,
And tones in which my thoughts were all conceived.
Oâer its loved crags and mountains did the air
Breathe more like life than other air to me;â
The very faults were dear which met me there,â
They spoke the land of my nativity.

lg.head: LXXI.
lg.l: âTo wander freely oâer my native hills,
To talk with others in my native tongue,
To feel in her renown such worth, as steals
From the landâs actions oâer her humblest throng:
This was my boyish joy, my manhoodâs pride,
Ambitionâs utmost,âyet was this denied.
Ah! dark in Memory frowns the bitter day,
When from my country I was forced away;
And still lookâd back upon the lessening shore,
Which seemâd a cloud, a shadow on the sea;
Yet held within its outline, thus obscure,
The cliffs, the streams, the home, lifeâs life and joy to me.

lg.head: LXXII.
lg.l: I came to sunny climes, where Natureâs mirth
And Natureâs tenderest softness seemed to twine;
Which they who callâd them theirs, deemed first of Earthâ
I blamed them not, for so to me were mine.
I saw fair scenes; but, ah! they only brought
Remembrance of far dearer to my thought,
Till tears the present image veilâd, and then
Behind their mists the lost land rose again;
That land which smiled, although I saw it not,
And wore the aspect I had watchâd for years,
Whose motherâimage is by none forgot,
Stampâd by the joy of youth, burnâd in by manhoodâd tears.

lg.head: LXXIII.
lg.l: âThen, wretched exile! would I sit me down,
Where some high point lookâd furthest oâer the Sea,
And gaze towards the spot whole hours alone,
Where home and native land were once for me.
And if the billows inward sent their spray,
And told of breezes winging thence their way,
I bent my knee to feel that wind pass oâer,
Which had been where I fain would be once more;
I sent my sighs on the returning air,
I spread mine arms toward the viewless shore;
My bosom centred all its yearnings there,
To Friendshipâs accents deaf, to Loveâs best kindness sore.

lg.head: LXXIV.
lg.l: âAt length, at length,âoh day, whose burst of bliss
I dreamâd not then, and understand not now!â
The word was spoke that ended woe like this,
The ban was taken from my exiled brow.
A storm raged wild: I thankâd kind Heaven, and gave
My wealth to one to bear me oâer the wave;
And, like a seaâbird, oâer the billowâs snow
Sped my wild bark, and yet I deemâd it slow.
Night fell, and all was hidden in its veil,â
The Morning dawnâd, and port and peak were nigh;
Oh, human strength could little then avail!
The heart, half broke with woe, now burst at once for joy.

lg.head: LXXV.
lg.l: âSo died I, gazing on the land I loved,
By joyâs forgotten passion oâerâoppressâd;
It killed the feeble frame through which it movedâ
The soul was grown too powârless to be blessâd.
Hope died within it, Pleasure sank subdued,
And Grief alone became its natural mood.
Awhile I wanderâd viewless upon Earth,
And grieved while gazing eâen on my homeâs hearth.
On mountain ridge and lakeâs lone shore I sighâd,
And swept in wailing winds oâer Oceanâd tide;
Until to happier souls awhile âtwas given
To make the land they, too, had loved, their heaven.
Then, from their presence sent, I had my place
Here, where the wretched of existence dwell;
A land create, perchance, for good and grace,
But âtis to me, like all beside, a hell!â

lg.head: LXXVI.
lg.l: âFeeble thou wert,â another Spectre cried,
Who wore a female shape, and sate apart,
As though her grief, unmatchâd by aught beside,
Stood kingâlike, amid many a broken heart.
âFeeble thou wert; and what except Dismay
Couldâst hope when Earthâs few years were passâd away;
And with them borne the clay, the rill, the tree,
Which make up homeâs best portraiture to thee?
Home is not there, where flows thâ accustomâd tide;
Not in the vale that breathes a native air;
Not in the hearth that we have lived beside,â
It is the living forms, who were Companions there.

lg.head: LXXVII.
lg.l: âOh, I had gone wherever snow or sun
Froze Natureâs breast, or coverâd it with flowârs;
And if meanwhile on mine I bore my son,
Had thought each scene we passâd my native bowârs.
I knew not where more precious breezes blew,
Save as they touchâd his cheek with healthier hue;
I markâd not where there shone a bluer sky,
Save as reflected from his brighter eye.
There was my mirror of the world without,
My altar for the world beyond our view;
Through him, and to him passâd, each social thought,
And worship of that gift was all the creed I knew.

lg.head: LXXVIII.
lg.l: âMy Boy, my Firstâborn, my Beatitude,
Died on this nursing breast, that flowâd in vain;
Pain in those eyes that used to seek me stood,
The clasping fingers now were stretchâd by pain:
And when they glazed and stiffenâd, what was I?
A Mother, and beheld my firstâborn die!
Oh! surely then my part on earth was done,
My time passâd by, my aim and purpose gone.
I, too, must die! and from that hour unblest,
Food I refused, and starved the vital flame.
Could I have borne to feel it fill my breast,
And have no cherub lip to drink it when it came?

lg.head: LXXIX.
lg.l: âThey spoke of comfort, but I closed the ear
That used to listen to my Infantâs strain;
That voice was gone, and neâer should one less dear,
With baser sounds, the Motherâs ear profane.
They fain would join my hands and lift my eyes,
In prayer submissive, toward the angry skies;
But, no! He gave the treasure that was gone;
He bound my soul about that taken one;
And I, obedient more to Natureâs call,
Claspâd my cold boy, and wept upon his pall.
I, too, was ready, since his time was done;
And when full soon upon him closed the tomb,
True to the thoughts which through my life had run,
I died upon his grave, whose birthâplace was my womb.â

lg.head: LXXX.
lg.l: Thus spake, thus paused they, and with frame oppressâd,
